posts.name: Will Rueter
posts.cooked: Swerve drive is up and running, can do translational movement well enough, however I cannot rotate and translate at the same time. When I rotate in place, the gyro seems accurate for a while, until at some arbitrary value (I’ve seen 160, 240, 270 degrees), it just stops moving, and just stays roughly around that value, with some noise. When I stop rotating the chassis, the values begin moving again, steadily decreasing until they hit some arbitrary value. Any idea why this is happening?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: How are you communicating with the NavX?  I’ve had problems with everything other than SPI.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Will Rueter
posts.cooked: Using SPI, which is the default for SwerveDriveSpecialties example code. I haven’t changed the example code other than angle offsets.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Might be a defective gyro, then.  Hopefully you have a spare?

posts.name: Adrian Hayden
posts.cooked: Were you unable to effectively use a USB connection?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Yes; the serial connection seemed to block frequently.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Adrian Hayden
posts.cooked: Ugh, I was planning on using USB. Is there record of other people having this issue?

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
Have you read the NavX interface recommendations?

The navX2-MXP /navX-MXP sensors provide several methods for communicating with robotics control applications: MXP I2C MXP SPI USB 2.0 Streaming vs. Register-based Communication The navX-MXP interfa…

posts.name: Adrian Hayden
posts.cooked: Yes, and that was why I was intending on USB. It’s faster than I2C, and the latency is 10x better. Plus, it’s streaming instead of register-based. I started looking at USB originally because of max cable length

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked: Might be worth running with this tool, to eliminate several possible variables (it uses USB, FWIW).  Also, never hurts to check that you are running current firmware.

posts.name: slibert
posts.cooked: It’s not clear which navX-sensor you are using, but if it’s the navX2-MXP or Micro, it’s highly recommended to check your firmware version to make sure it’s up to date.

posts.name: JJ Sessa
posts.cooked:
We also had identical issues with the navx2 mxp. Spi, usb backup power, checking logs for brownouts, still couldn’t get it to not drop off every 10min of practice randomly for 3-4 seconds.

Switched to pigeon for TT, CC, and BB, no issues.

Plan to test the navx2 mini in the coming months.
